The .50 Browning Machine Gun (12.7?99mm NATO and designated as the 50 Browning by the C.I.P.) is a cartridge developed for the Browning .50 caliber machine gun in the late 1910s, entering official service in 1921. Under STANAG 4383, it is a standard cartridge for NATO forces as well as many non-NATO countries. The cartridge itself has been made in many variants: multiple generations of regular ball, tracer, armor-piercing (AP), incendiary, and saboted sub-caliber . The intended for machine guns are made into a continuous belt using metallic links. 
The .50 BMG cartridge is also used in long-range target and anti-materiel rifles, as well as other .50-caliber machine guns. 
 
%c[d_purple] • %c[ui_gray_2] Najwy¿sza przebita klasa pancerza: %c[ui_gray_1]IV 
%c[d_purple] • %c[ui_gray_2] Poziom uszkodzenia tkanki: %c[ui_gray_1]wysoki

Posiada œwietne w³aœciwoœci penetruj¹ce; mo¿e z ³atwoœci¹ przebiæ siê przez l¿ejsze kamizelki balistyczne oraz kewlarowe he³my.
